e_subTitle: Follow your coach’s directions to explore the LHOQ.

introModal.e_title: Exploring the Linear House of Quality
introModal.e_text:
In this activity, you’ll explore the LHOQ to demonstrate how it translates the voice of the customer (design input) into product specifications and materials (design outputs).

Your LHOQ exploration will prepare you to walk through the DQM, which uses data compiled in the LHOQ.

Ready? Let’s begin!

conclusionModal.e_title: That Completes Your Tour of the Linear House of Quality!
conclusionModal.e_text:
You have now reviewed the LHOQ as a tool that unites the voice of the customer with the voice of the process. This union includes the product design, specifications, raw materials, and end-product characteristics.

As mentioned, part of the LHOQ is used to create the DQM. Let’s learn more about that connection now.

toolPage.e_subtitle: Select the image numbers at the bottom of the screen to see the sheets in each LHOQ tab.

parts.e_questionText: What do you believe happens if total comparison scores for importance between one or more customer wants results in a tie?

prompts.e_prompt:
Before House 1 of the LHOQ is explored, a tab exists in the tool to begin an analysis of the voice of the customer: Customer Wants. Our exploration begins here.

Select the X in the right corner to advance to the next screen in this activity.
Select each are highlighted in yellow on the LHOQ to learn more.

e_popups:
In this column, the team enters a list of the customer wants from initial discovery insights. This isn't intended to capture everything, but will help the team focus on the critical wants and needs throughout commercialization.

Examples of customer wants and needs might be:

“I want the container to open easily.”
“I want the cleaning solution to not leave a smear.”“I don’t want the product to break easily.”

Completing this section is often a team effort to capture different perspectives of the target customer.

Quality inspects the accuracy of the Customer Wants list and how it is carried into House 1 of the LHOQ.

Here, each item from the list of customer wants and needs is given an importance ranking:
  • Critical

  • Important

  • Nice to Have

  • Not as Important

Critical items must be captured for a product design to reflect the voice of the customer. While the entire team contributes to the completion of the LHOQ, Quality pays close attention to content and the team's execution throughout the process.

The results of a paired comparison of the customer wants are automatically recorded in the rows to the right based on what you entered in Column B.

For any customer wants in the columns that are higher in importance to those in the corresponding rows in Column B, change the cell values from a 1 to a 0.

This changes the calculations used to rank the customer needs against one another.

choices.e_text: The tied customer wants will need to be equally represented in the steps that will follow
choices.e_feedback:
Not Quite.

While this may seem like a reasonable conclusion, the standard for use of the LHOQ calls for another action. Try again by selecting the X at the upper right corner.

choices.e_text: A tie must be broken to complete the ranking process
choices.e_feedback:
You got it!

It is standard when using the LHOQ that total comparison score ties need to be broken. Select X to continue.

choices.e_text: No action needs to be taken
choices.e_feedback:
Not Quite.

In the event of a tie, there is an action to take. Try again.

parts.e_questionText: What do you think happens if a correlation between a customer want and a linked performance method returns a 0 or 1 result?

prompts.e_prompt:
Once the team identifies and ranks customer wants, the information can be brought in to populate the 1st House: Customer Wants, as seen on the right.

We will spend most of our time exploring House 1 as it is used to begin completion of the DQM.

Select the X to begin exploring now.
Select each highlighted area on the LHOQ to learn more.

e_popups:
In this column, performance measures are defined by Lab to ensure the customer wants are quantified. Note these are not test methods, but are controlled factors that will eventually be tested.

More than one performance measure can be tied to a single customer want.

Quality checks these measurements to ensure they are feasible.

Here, Lab records the strength of correlation between each customer want and a corresponding performance measure using a scale:

0: No correlation
1. Slight correlation
3. Moderate correlation
9. Strong correlation

Correlations of 0 or 1 need to be investigated by the team, including Quality, as higher correlations are necessary to ensure quality.

choices.e_text: The performance method needs to be revised
choices.e_feedback:
You got it!

If a performance method does not have a strong correlation with a customer want, then it cannot be used confidently to determine a test method for the identified customer want.

Select X to continue.

choices.e_text: The customer want should be excluded from the list
choices.e_feedback:
Oops, not quite.

At this point it is premature to begin excluding any customer wants entirely. Try again.

choices.e_text: The correlation statistics must be wrong
choices.e_feedback:
Not Quite.

While it is possible that the statistics used to obtain a correlation should be run a second time, you don’t want to assume that the statistics are wrong as your first conclusion. The performance method may simply be inappropriate for the identified customer want. Try again.

prompts.e_prompt: Product characteristics are also matched to customer wants in this next section of House 1, including similar testing for strength of correlation completed for performance measures. Higher correlations are best while lower correlations require investigation.

You are now in the 2nd House: Test methods and product characteristics.

In this section, we will examine the importance of selecting appropriate test methods.

Select X to continue.
Select each highlighted area on the LHOQ to learn more.

e_popups: Here, Lab records the test method name and number. More than one test method can be tied to a single product characteristic identified and substantiated in House 1.

In this column, test methods are identified as being used for product design development, manufacturing release, or both. Each team member contributes to or references the information collected here in some way.

Later, process variables and raw material characteristics are documented and evaluated for test methods and their linked product characteristics.

prompts.e_prompt:
Here are some of the additional test methods and material consideration aspects of House 2 at a glance. Lab evaluates the results of test methods to ensure product specifications are within close proximity to what customers will expect, i.e., they fall within customer tolerances. Lab and Manufacturing populate this section, while Quality inspects to improve the process if needed.

Take a moment to review this screen and then select X to continue.

parts.e_questionText:
Let’s say a test method included in a collection of similar tests fully captures the product characteristic on its own.

What might you do from the Quality perspective?

prompts.e_prompt: Lab tests Strength of Correlation again to evaluate test methods to product characteristics, followed by collections of test methods to product characteristics. Similar test methods should return similar correlations. Decisions regarding these tests can then be recorded in the tool.

choices.e_text: Add more test methods to the collection to make testing more robust
choices.e_feedback:
Close, but not quite.

While this wouldn’t necessarily cause any harm, it probably wouldn’t drive efficiency of the process. Try again.

choices.e_text: Select the test method in question in favor of using a collection of methods for the product characteristic
choices.e_feedback:
Good thinking!

Lab may not need to continually use a set of tests if a single test demonstrates it can fully characterize a product characteristic reliably.

Note that a test method should be demonstrated to measure a product characteristic validly and reliably. Not all test methods will perform equally. Identifying the best ones is part of the process.

Select X to continue.

choices.e_text: No action needs to be taken
choices.e_feedback:
Not Quite.

There is an opportunity here. Try again.

prompts.e_prompt: To end our tour of House 2, Product Targets and Specifications and Product Control Limits and Capability are also tested and evaluated. These sections identify upper and lower limits for product specifications and for manufacturing. Specification limits should represent the maximum allowable limits the customer would find acceptable. Release limits should represent a narrower range within the specification limits that can account for process variability.

You’ve now reached the 3rd House: Process Variables and Raw Material Properties That Predict Product Characteristics. This is the point where you can see how the journey of translating customer wants reaches the expected end-product characteristics.
Select each highlighted area on the LHOQ to learn more.

e_popups:
Here, the team defines the process step at which each product characteristic is imparted.

Process steps are the series of actions and tasks to manufacture the product or solution to specific and defined standards and tests.

More than one process step may be responsible for imparting a product characteristic.

Once product characteristics and process steps have been paired, Lab uses this column to define the process variable or raw material characteristic tied to that pairing.

Process variables are parts of a process being monitored or controlled.

Raw material characteristics can include physical, chemical, and/or performance properties of an input material.

As seen earlier in our exploration, Lab conducts correlations between process variables or raw material characteristics and their corresponding product characteristic to ensure the correct materials are now linked to product characteristics for manufacturing.

parts.e_questionText:
Which of the following could be identified as problems when control limits and capability are evaluated?

Hint: There are two correct answers.

e_correct.text:
Good Thinking!

Product characteristics are evaluated to ensure they fall within the control limits related to selected raw materials used for production. As decisions or trade-offs are made to achieve this, the design of the product should also not fall below customer tolerances.

e_incorrect.text:
Not quite.

Consider the voice of the customer (their expectations) and the voice of the process (what production can do) and try this question again.

prompts.e_prompt: Analysis continues in House 3 to include additional methods of measuring process variable and raw material measurements, targets and specifications, and control limits and capability. Control limits are related to product robustness and describe what a process can produce.

choices.e_text: Critical product characteristics drifting outside the control limit
Test data from validation falls within control limits
An alternative raw material is identified
Test data is off-center of the specification and capability is low

prompts.e_prompt:
We'll end our exploration with the 4th House: Controls.
The purpose of this House is entering the control methods to ensure the process variables are met.
Select each highlighted area on the LHOQ to learn more.

e_popups:
For each process variable identified in House 3, Lab defines a control method to ensure the process variable or raw material characteristic remains within a selected target range.

This is determined, once again, by correlation analysis by individual control methods and by collections of control methods.

Lab records the effectiveness of control methods with their location documented.

This ensures the previous analysis results and the target ranges identified can be accessible by the team and future teams performing similar work.
